title: U.S. stock futures wipe out gains after smaller-than-expected slowdown in inflation; Oil surges amid signs of easing COVID cases in China
text:
* S&P 500 futures ES00 fell 23.75 points, or 0.7%, to 3,973.

* Dow Jones Industrial Average futures YM00 dropped 109 points, or 0.3%, to 31,978.

* Nasdaq 100 futures NQ00 shed 124 points, or 1% to 12,225.

On Tuesday, the Dow industrials DJIA fell 0.3% to close at 32,160.74, a fourth straight day of losses that marked its largest four-day percentage decline since the stretch ending Oct. 29, 2020. The S&P 500 SPX snapped a three-day losing streak with a gain of 0.2%, while the Nasdaq Composite COMP advanced 1%.

What's driving markets?

Gains for stock-index futures were erased after data showed April consumer prices rose at an 8.3% annual pacein April, slowing from a more-than-40-year high of 8.6% in March. But it was above the 8.1% pace expected by economists surveyed by The Wall Street Journal and underscored that inflation continues to run at a torrid pace.

However, the so-called core rate of inflation, which omits food and energy, rose by a somewhat stronger 0.6%. Wall Street had forecast a 0.4% increase. The increase in the core rate over the past year also slowed to 6.2% from from a 40-year high of 6.5% in March.

"Risk assets are under pressure with equity futures red on the assumption this will compel the Fed to extend the 50 [basis point] cadence [on rate hikes] beyond the June/July meetings already signaled," said Ian Lyngen, rates strategist at BMO Capital Markets, in a note.

Opinion: The Fed doesn't deserve all of the blame for this inflation surge

The federal budget for April is due at 2 p.m. Eastern Time.

Some positive sentiment could also be fueled by reports that COVID cases were easing in Beijing and Shanghai, driving hopes for an easing of restrictions and pressure on the global economy. Optimism that that could relay to improved demand helped drive oil prices sharply higher.

Read: Ukrainians make gains in east, as country halts Russian gas at one hub

Separately, data showed China's consumer-price index rose 2.1% in Aprilfrom a year earlier, picking up from March's 1.5% increase.

Treasury yields jumped after the data, with that of the 10-year note BX:TMUBMUSD10Y up 3.3 basis points to 3.032%

Big earnings news in focus after the close of markets will fall on The Walt Disney Co. DIS, whose shares rose 1% in premarket trade. Investors will be taking a close look at the entertainment giant's streaming servicein particular, after rival Netflix NFLX reported slumping subscriber numbers last month.

Which companies are in focus?

* Coinbase Global Inc. COIN shares fell 14% in premarket trade as the crypto trading app reported worse-than-forecast revenue on declining volume.

* Switch Inc. SWCH stock rose 8% on news that DigitalBridge Group Inc. DBRG has offered to buy the technology group in a cash deal valued at $11 billion.

* Perrigo PLC PRGO shares fell 4% in premarket trade after the personal self-care product maker swung to a first-quarter loss, missing estimates.

* Krispy Kreme Inc. DNUT shares rose 2.4% in premarket trading after the doughnut seller reported forecast-beating profit and revenue and affirmed its full-year outlook.

How are other assets trading?

* Oil futures surged, with the U.S. benchmark CL00 CL.1 CLM22 up $4 , or 4%, to $103.79 a barrel, with Brent crude BRN00 BRNN22 up nearly $4, or 3.8%, to $106.39 a barrel.

* Gold futures GC00 rose, with gold for June delivery GCM22 up 0.5% to $1,848.90 an ounce.

* The Stoxx Europe 600 XX:SXXP rose 1.3%, while London's FTSE 100 UK:UKX rose 0.9%.

* The Shanghai Composite CN:SHCOMProse 0.7%, while the Hang Seng Index HK:HSI gained 0.9% and Japan's Nikkei 225 JP:NIK was up 0.1%.

U.S. stock futures wipe out gains after smaller-than-expected slowdown in inflation
